question_details.title: Will the study of chlorine distribution in Sierra Leone find a statistically significant increase in chlorine usage by the recipients?
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-10-23 16:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/28371). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

In May 2024, GiveWell made a [grant](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#Internal_forecasts) to Wageningen University to add delivery of chlorine for disinfecting drinking water to a bundle of health services that is being delivered door-to-door in Sierra Leone, as part of a cluster-randomized controlled trial. This trial will study whether this distribution of chlorine will lead to a statistically significant increase in chlorine usage:

>The study will be a cluster-randomized [randomized controlled trial] in which the treatment communities receive household-to-household visits from health teams offering routine childhood and HPV vaccines to those who have not received all of the vaccines in the vaccination schedule. Households with children under the age of 5 will also be offered VAS, deworming pills, chlorine to treat drinking water, and ORS/zinc to treat future diarrhea episodes [[1](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#footnote1)]. Control communities will not receive any interventions [[2](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#footnote2)]. The health teams will also provide information on when young children are due for subsequent vaccines [[3](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#footnote3)]. The health teams will return after three months and provide the same bundle of services [[4](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#footnote4)].

>Data on vaccination, VAS, and deworming uptake will be collected at the same time as delivery at both the initial visit and the 3-month follow-up visit, and simultaneously in control communities [[5](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#footnote5)]. At the 3-month visit, households will also be asked about use of chlorine and ORS/zinc, and the survey team will test household water for chlorine [[6](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#footnote6)]. Chlorine and ORS/zinc usage will be measured just at the 3-month visit, as unlike the other commodities, take-up of these products cannot be measured right away [[7](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#footnote7)]. 

As of May 2024, the estimated usage of chlorine in these communities was about 8% and the study is powered to detect a minimum effect size of 5 percentage points. If that increase in chlorine use was achieved, it would mean at least 13% usage in the treatment group. GiveWell's internal forecasting offers a probability of 80% that the study will measure a statistically significant increase in chlorine usage in the treatment group, combined over two rounds of distribution.

According to [the grant rationale](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024#The_case_for_the_grant), GiveWell has high confidence in the research team and thinks they will be able to achieve the sample size needed to detect effects in chlorine usage. GiveWell’s reservations about the potential outcomes include:

- Recipients may be overwhelmed by the quantity of health services being received in the door-to-door visits and may not process all the instructions.
- Recipients may view oral rehydration solution and chlorine as substitutes for each other.
- People in areas with very little contact with health authorities might not react to the health information in ways that researchers would hope.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question resolves as **Yes** if, before January 1, 2026, the GiveWell-funded [study](https://www.givewell.org/research/grants/wageningen-university-sierra-leone-rct-2024) by Wageningen University and its affiliated research team finds a statistically significant increase in chlorine usage by the treatment group over two rounds of distribution of chlorine to certain household clusters in Sierra Leone, compared with the control group. 

If no statistically significant increase is found, whether because none occurs, there is insufficient data, or the study is not completed before January 1, 2026, this question resolves as **No**.
question_details.fine_print:
According to the Yale Research Initiative on Innovation and Scale, the minimal detectable effect for chlorine use is estimated to be very low (5 percentage points; [pdf source](https://files.givewell.org/files/DWDA%202009/YRISE/Givewell_Research_Proposal_on_YRISE_vaccines.pdf), p. 11) for this study, and the current estimate of usage is very low (8%; Ibid., p. 20).

In assessing the statistical significance in the comparison between the control group and treatment group, please note that the p-value must be < 0.05.

In case of reporting delays, resolution will wait up to two years after the end of the question period, until December 31, 2027, after which the question will be **annulled** if Metaculus determines there is insufficient evidence to support a **Yes** or **No** resolution.

**Second flu vaccine dose boosts protection in young, vaccine-naive kids, analysis suggests**
A meta-analysis of 51 studies involving 415,050 vaccine-naive children aged 6 months to 8 years, published in JAMA Network Open on October 3, 2025, found that a second dose of inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV) significantly increases vaccine effectiveness (VE) by 28 percentage points (from 52% to 80%) in children younger than 3 years. However, no statistically significant benefit was observed when the age range was expanded to children younger than 9 years, with a 15-percentage-point increase (from 43% to 58%). The pooled VE for one dose of IIV was 14% for children under 3 years and 35% for those up to 8 years. For live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV), pooled one-dose VE was 26%, similar to one-dose IIV VE (35%), but second-dose LAIV efficacy was significantly higher at 82%. The authors noted that the difference in efficacy between LAIV and IIV may reflect seasonal antigenic variation rather than inherent vaccine superiority. Most studies (23 of 28) categorized children as partially or fully vaccinated rather than by dose count, with pooled VE of 32% for partial vaccination and 43% for full vaccination. The researchers emphasized that few randomized controlled trials assessed the protection of one versus two doses in the same population and that many observational studies were at high risk of bias due to misclassification. They concluded that the second IIV dose provides meaningful additional protection for vaccine-naive children under 3, but the benefit diminishes with age, and more high-quality studies are needed to determine the optimal age range for a two-dose schedule for both vaccine types.

**Effect of zinc-containing pessaries on menopausal genitourinary syndrome, a double-blind randomised trial - BMC Women's Health**
A double-blind randomized trial conducted from December 2021 to December 2022 at Ashmoun Central Hospital in Elmenofia, Egypt, evaluated the effect of zinc-containing pessaries on symptoms of genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM)/vulvovaginal atrophy (VVA). The study included 50 postmenopausal women who met inclusion criteria: amenorrhea for at least 12 months or serum follicle-stimulating hormone >30 mIU/mL, along with symptoms such as vaginal dryness, burning, itching, pain, dyspareunia, and dysuria. Exclusion criteria included history of gynecological or breast cancer, pelvic organ prolapse, recent use of vaginal products or douching (within 3 months), or hormone therapy (within 6 months). Participants were randomly assigned to two groups of 25: Group 1 received zinc sulfate-containing pessaries, and Group 2 received placebo pessaries, both administered vaginally before bedtime for 14 consecutive nights. Pessaries were identical in appearance, using a glycerol-gelatine base, with zinc sulfate and lactic acid incorporated into the active group. Randomization codes were managed by an independent pharmacy at Cairo University, and blinding was maintained for participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors. Outcomes were assessed using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for symptom severity (0–10), the Vaginal Health Index (VHI) for elasticity, secretion, pH, epithelial mucosa, and hydration (1–5, lower = worse), and the Vaginal Maturation Index (VMI) calculated as [(1×%superficial) + (0.5×%intermediate) + (0×%parabasal)]. Assessments were performed before and after treatment. A satisfaction questionnaire was administered two weeks post-treatment. Data were analyzed using SPSS 22.0; statistical significance was set at p < 0.05. The primary outcome was the effect of zinc-containing pessaries on GSM/VVA symptoms.

**Health ministry advisory calls for 'rational use' of cough syrups for children**
The Directorate General of Health Services, under the Union Health Ministry, issued an advisory urging the 'rational use' of cough syrups for children following the deaths of eight children aged one to seven in Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan, allegedly due to cough syrup poisoning. The advisory emphasizes that most acute cough illnesses in children are self-limiting and do not require pharmacological treatment. It explicitly advises against prescribing cough and cold medications for children under two years and discourages their use in children under five, stating that any use above age five must involve careful clinical evaluation, strict adherence to dosing, shortest effective duration, and avoidance of multiple drug combinations. The advisory promotes non-pharmacological measures such as 'adequate hydration and rest' as first-line treatment. It also mandates that health facilities procure and dispense products made under Good Manufacturing Practices with pharmaceutical-grade excipients. While tests on samples from Madhya Pradesh found no Diethylene Glycol (DEG) or Ethylene Glycol (EG), and samples from Rajasthan showed no Propylene Glycol, the Union Health Ministry stated that the products were dextromethorphan-based formulations, which are not recommended for pediatric use. This follows a 2022 global alert by the World Health Organization after 66 deaths in The Gambia were linked to contaminated cough syrups from a Haryana-based manufacturer. The usual cause of toxicity is the substitution of industrial-grade glycerine or propylene glycol for pharmaceutical-grade versions, which can lead to acute kidney injury and death. In July 2024, over 100 pharmaceutical units across India failed quality control tests for cough syrups.

**Second flu vaccine dose boosts protection in young, vaccine-naive kids, analysis suggests**
A meta-analysis of 51 studies involving 415,050 vaccine-naive children aged 6 months to 8 years, published in JAMA Network Open on October 3, 2025, found that a second dose of inactivated influenza vaccine (IIV) significantly increases vaccine effectiveness (VE) by 28 percentage points (from 52% to 80%) in children younger than 3 years. However, no statistically significant benefit was observed when the age range was expanded to children younger than 9 years, with a 15-percentage-point increase (from 43% to 58%). The pooled VE for one dose of IIV was 14% for children under 3 years and 35% for those up to 8 years. For live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV), pooled one-dose VE was 26%, similar to one-dose IIV VE (35%), but second-dose LAIV efficacy was significantly higher at 82%. The authors noted that the difference in efficacy between LAIV and IIV may reflect seasonal antigenic variation rather than inherent vaccine superiority. Most studies (23 of 28) categorized children as partially or fully vaccinated rather than by dose count, with pooled VE of 32% for partial vaccination and 43% for full vaccination. The researchers emphasized that few randomized controlled trials assessed the protection of one versus two doses in the same population and that many observational studies were at high risk of bias due to misclassification. They concluded that the second IIV dose provides meaningful additional protection for vaccine-naive children under 3, but the benefit diminishes with age, and more high-quality studies are needed to determine the optimal age range for a two-dose schedule for both vaccine types.

**Snapshot on nutrition awareness, behaviors and practices among Galkayo IDPs**

**Effect of zinc-containing pessaries on menopausal genitourinary syndrome, a double-blind randomised trial - BMC Women's Health**
A double-blind randomized trial conducted from December 2021 to December 2022 at Ashmoun Central Hospital in Elmenofia, Egypt, evaluated the effect of zinc-containing pessaries on symptoms of genitourinary syndrome of menopause (GSM)/vulvovaginal atrophy (VVA). The study included 50 postmenopausal women who met inclusion criteria: amenorrhea for at least 12 months or serum follicle-stimulating hormone >30 mIU/mL, along with symptoms such as vaginal dryness, burning, itching, pain, dyspareunia, and dysuria. Exclusion criteria included history of gynecological or breast cancer, pelvic organ prolapse, recent use of vaginal products or douching (within 3 months), or hormone therapy (within 6 months). Participants were randomly assigned to two groups of 25: Group 1 received zinc sulfate-containing pessaries, and Group 2 received placebo pessaries, both administered vaginally before bedtime for 14 consecutive nights. Pessaries were identical in appearance, using a glycerol-gelatine base, with zinc sulfate and lactic acid incorporated into the active group. Randomization codes were managed by an independent pharmacy at Cairo University, and blinding was maintained for participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors. Outcomes were assessed using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for symptom severity (0–10), the Vaginal Health Index (VHI) for elasticity, secretion, pH, epithelial mucosa, and hydration (1–5, lower = worse), and the Vaginal Maturation Index (VMI) calculated as [(1×%superficial) + (0.5×%intermediate) + (0×%parabasal)]. Assessments were performed before and after treatment. A satisfaction questionnaire was administered two weeks post-treatment. Data were analyzed using SPSS 22.0; statistical significance was set at p < 0.05. The primary outcome was the effect of zinc-containing pessaries on GSM/VVA symptoms.
